In the mid 1700's the Coastal and Piedmont regions of North Carolina were distinctly different and separate. Because the lifestyle of the Piedmont settler was primarily farming for their own family and barter of their crops and services with their neighbors, they didn't produce a monetary income so had little to no cash when it came time to pay taxes. As a result, many of the farmers fell into significant debt. Many of these Piedmont settler farmers believed they were being overtaxed by the county and Colonial officials in Hillsborough and that too much was expected of their modest yeoman farms.
